channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israeli Cabinet Deal Would Save West Bank From Economic Crisis, at a Price
item.description: Israel has dealt blow after financial blow to the Palestinian Authority, alarming the United States, which wants it to have a role in running postwar Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Iran’s 2024 Presidential Election: What to Know
item.description: Iran will hold a special election on Friday to replace former President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash in May.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching a presidential debate on a screen this month in Tehran.

item.title: Racist and Homophobic Comments Unsettle U.K. Election Campaign
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak denounced a slur used against him by a man campaigning for Reform U.K., the anti-immigration party led by Nigel Farage.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain campaigning in Leeds, England, on Thursday. He told broadcasters that “it hurts and it makes me angry” that his two daughters “have to see and hear Reform people who campaigned for Nigel Farage” using such offensive language directed at their father.

item.title: Iran Holds Vote to Pick a President
item.description: The latest polling suggested Dr. Masoud Pezeshkian, a reformist candidate, was in the lead, but not enough to avoid a runoff.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Saeed Jalili, the ultraconservative Iranian presidential candidate, gathered in Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Iran’s Presidential Candidates: Who Are They?
item.description: Four of the six candidates selected by officials to run in Iran’s special presidential election are still in the running after the president died in a helicopter crash last month.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters of Gen. Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf, current speaker of Parliament and a presidential candidate, in the streets of Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Debates in U.K. and U.S. Differ Sharply in Tone and Substance
item.description: The debates between contenders to be U.K. prime minister showed that Britain’s political culture, and the leaders who have emerged from it, are far removed from those across the ocean.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The Labour Party leader Keir Starmer, left, and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak during a debate on Wednesday in Nottingham, Britain.

item.title: France’s Bold Election Gamble: Here Is What’s at Stake
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s surprise call for new elections in France’s lower house of Parliament is seen as a risky gamble.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The party of President Emmanuel Macron of France suffered a stinging defeat in European Parliament elections in early June.

item.title: Why Britain’s Murky Election Betting Scandal Is Causing Outrage
item.description: The embattled Conservative Party is embroiled in investigations over whether some of its own staff members used insider knowledge to bet on the timing of the general election.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announcing the next U.K. general election at 10 Downing Street in London last month.

item.title: U.S. Allies in Asia and Europe Watch the Debate With a Question: What Now?
item.description: Across Asia and Europe, the event stoked concerns about American stability, both domestically and on crucial foreign policy issues like Washington’s commitment to alliances.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Motoko Rich
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden’s weak debate performance had analysts and officials in Europe, Asia and beyond fretting about a return to office of Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Brittany Was Once Barren Ground for France’s Far Right. No More.
item.description: The region along the northwest coast has few immigrants and little crime or unemployment, but the far-right National Rally has made inroads saying that all three are coming.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:description: So many people from the small town of Gourin, in northwest France, emigrated to the United States over the decades, that Air France gave it a miniature State of Liberty.

item.title: Kenya Protesters Call for President to Resign Despite His Withdrawal of the Tax Bill
item.description: The demonstrations were held despite his withdrawal of the tax bill that sparked days of protests. Some activists, fearing more bloodshed, warned people not to march to the president’s official residence.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A protester enveloped in a cloud of tear gas taunts a Kenyan anti-riot police officer in downtown Nairobi, on Thursday.

item.title: At Least 750,000 on Brink of Starvation and Death in Sudan, Experts Warn
item.description: A devastating civil war is pushing the country toward a full-blown famine, according to the international body that measures hunger.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 20-month-old, Bara’a Ahmed, being treated in the malnutrition unit at a hospital in Port Sudan in April. Conditions have worsened sharply since last year, a global body says.

item.title: Julian Assange’s Polarizing Legacy: From Hacker to Hunted Figure
item.description: The co-founder of WikiLeaks was a heroic crusader for truth to many people for publishing government secrets. To others, he was a reckless leaker endangering lives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Julian Assange arriving at Canberra Airport in Canberra, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Is King Charles III About to Get a Prime Minister He Likes?
item.description: The British monarch is constitutionally barred from any role in politics. But experts say that Charles and the leader of the Labour Party, Keir Starmer, have much in common.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles and the Labour leader, Keir Starmer, at Buckingham Palace in 2022. “There’s a meeting of minds in terms of the social issues at stake,” one historian said about the two men.

item.title: Putin Vows to Make New Nuclear Missiles and Weigh Putting Them Near NATO Nations
item.description: The announcement appeared to be the Russian leader’s latest attempt to raise the stakes in his conflict with the West, coming less than two weeks after his visit to North Korea.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia made the announcement just as major elections were about to begin in Britain and France.

item.title: Doris Allen, Analyst Who Saw the Tet Offensive Coming, Is Dead at 97
item.description: Her warning of a big buildup of enemy troops poised to attack South Vietnam in 1968 was ignored, a major U.S. Army intelligence failure during the war.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Before LeBron and Bronny, These Fathers and Sons Made Sports History
item.description: The Los Angeles Lakers are poised to have the first father-son N.B.A. duo in league history. But other dads and sons have played pro sports together as well.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Left: Raul Romero Jr./Associated Press, Right: Matthew Stockman, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bronny James could play on the same team this fall as his father, the basketball great LeBron James.

item.title: U.S. Presses to Avert Wider War Between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon
item.description: A recent flurry of diplomacy aims to head off a conflict that could pit the United States directly against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Julian E. Barnes and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An armored United Nations vehicle driving through the heavily damaged village of Kfar Kila, in southern Lebanon, earlier this month.

item.title: Dutch Olympic Organizers Defend Participation of Athlete Convicted of Rape
item.description: Steven van de Velde, a beach volleyball player, spent time in prison for the 2014 rape of a 12-year-old girl. His inclusion on the Olympic team has caused a stir in the international news media.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Pablo Morano/BSR Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Steven van de Velde of the Netherlands, seen competing in Mexico last year, qualified for the Dutch Olympic beach volleyball team this year. In 2016, Mr. van de Velde was convicted of rape.

item.title: Mikhail Baryshnikov on Leaving Everything Behind
item.description: Fifty years ago, Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union. He discusses that day, the war in Ukraine and the challenges facing Russian artists today.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It was the start of a new life,” Mikhail Baryshnikov says of the night in 1974 that he dodged K.G.B. agents in Toronto as he rushed to meet Canadian and American friends in a getaway car.

item.title: At Euro 2024, a Very England Fight Misses the Point
item.description: A back and forth over the pundit’s one-word analysis of his country’s performances rests on a misconception about the media’s role.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Kyle Walker and England ... ouch.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Tunneling to the Past
item.description: Looking for answers, or an escape, in a fraught world.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young man selling sweets walking through the destroyed streets of the Old City of Mosul, Iraq, in 2017.

item.title: Princess Anne Returns Home From the Hospital After Suffering Concussion
item.description: Anne, the younger sister of King Charles III, suffered a concussion and other injuries in an accident at her country residence, palace officials said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Princess Anne at Buckingham Palace in London last month.

item.title: For An Aquatic Veterinarian, It’s Never ‘Just A Fish’
item.description: Stress, ovarian cancer, buoyancy disorders: Every pet has its troubles, and needs a good doctor who makes house calls.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Nic Coury
item.media:description: Dr. Jessie Sanders analyzing the movement of a Fisher’s wood catfish at a home in Martinez, Calif., in January.

item.title: What the Impressionist Painter Camille Pissarro Saw in London
item.description: A writer used Camille Pissarro’s paintings of suburban London and a ‘lost’ railway as a lens for exploring the city’s history — and settling an arcane mystery.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Crystal Palace railway station is named for the large glass structure that was moved to Southeast London after the 1851 Great Exhibition. The structure later burned down.

item.title: 7.2-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Off Peru, Injures 3
item.description: A tsunami alert was lifted about an hour after the quake struck off the coast of the southern region of Arequipa.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: No Appendix, No Problem. Australia’s Remote Doctors Tell All.
item.description: Being the only physician around for hundreds of miles isn’t always bad. “It’s quite liberating to be like, ‘I’m the best person here for the job’,” said one doctor.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A training area replicating an aircraft that transports doctors who provide health care services for people living in remote areas of Australia.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Biden stumbled in the first 2024 debate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Former President Donald Trump and President Biden during their debate.

item.title: Roof Collapses at Delhi Airport Terminal Amid Storms and Heavy Rain
item.description: At least one person was killed when parts of the roof caved in and crushed vehicles at Indira Gandhi airport in New Delhi, according to an official. All domestic departures were suspended.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A crew inspecting the damage to a part of a canopy at New Delhi’s Indira Gandhi International Airport that collapsed on Friday.

item.title: President Luis Arce of Bolivia Confronts a Coup Attempt, and Evo Morales
item.description: After facing down the general who tried to oust him, President Luis Arce is battling a more formidable figure, Evo Morales, a former president who wants to reclaim power.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, María Silvia Trigo and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Soldiers in La Paz, the administrative capital of Bolivia, on Wednesday, during a failed coup attempt.

item.title: These Are the Officials Selected for the Top E.U. Jobs
item.description: Europe will need to navigate turmoil at home and a potential Trump presidency abroad. These people were picked to steer its institutions for the next five years.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, who has come into her own as an unexpected wartime leader for the European Union, was put forward for a second term as president of the European Commission.

item.title: Friday Briefing: What to Watch in the French Election
item.description: Also, the upcoming U.S. presidential debate and the vote in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte Macron in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Taiwanese Are Told to Avoid China After It Threatens Independence Backers
item.description: Beijing released new rules calling for execution of “diehard” Taiwanese independence supporters, as hostilities surrounding Taiwan’s status rise.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Watching coverage of China’s military drills around Taiwan last month in Beijing.

item.title: Critically Ill Children Allowed to Leave Gaza for First Time Since May
item.description: Israel said the operation was carried out in coordination with the U.S. and others, and that 68 people, including sick and injured patients and their escorts, were allowed to leave.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A Palestinian girl in a vehicle taking children out of Gaza for medical treatment abroad on Thursday.

item.title: Study Finds Small Streams, Recently Stripped of Protections, Are a Big Deal
item.description: Half of the water flowing through regional river basins starts in so-called ephemeral streams. Last year, the Supreme Court curtailed federal protections for these waterways.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A riparian area in Wells, Nev., in the northeastern part of the state. In the West, ephemeral streams flow only for four to 46 days per year, on average, but contribute up to 79 percent of the downstream river flow, new research has found.

item.title: As Iran Picks a President, a Nuclear Shift: Open Talk About Building the Bomb
item.description: Iran has expanded its most sensitive nuclear production site in recent weeks. And for the first time, some leaders are dropping their insistence that the nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard depicting some of Iran’s ballistic weaponry in Tehran in April. Iran’s nuclear expansion comes at the most delicate of moments.

item.title: The Last Stand of the Woolly Mammoths
item.description: The species survived on an island north of Siberia for thousands of years, scientists reported, but were most likely plagued by genetic abnormalities.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Russian Casualties in Ukraine Mount, in a Brutal Style of Fighting
item.description: More than 1,000 Russian soldiers in Ukraine were killed or wounded on average each day in May, according to NATO and Western military officials.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank in southern Ukraine earlier this spring. Russia lost an average of 1,000 soldiers per day during the war in Ukraine in May.

item.title: How to Escape From the Russian Army
item.description: Facing grim job prospects, a young Nepali signed up to join Russia’s military, which sent him to fight in Ukraine. His ordeal of combat, injury and escape turned into a tale worthy of Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Uma Bista for The New York Times
item.media:description: Desperate for a job, Krishna Bahadur Shahi joined the Russian military, believing — wrongly — that he would not be sent into battle.

item.title: China Levels Graft Charges Against Former Defense Ministers
item.description: The two generals were accused of taking huge bribes and of corruption that reached into the armaments sector, indicating that the country’s military has not shaken off old habits.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Gen. Li Shangfu, center, at a welcome ceremony in Singapore in 2023. He was China’s defense minister for much of last year.

item.title: Will Extreme Heat Hold Back Saudi Arabia and Other Gulf States?
item.description: The high temperatures blamed for the deaths of pilgrims in Saudi Arabia are taking a broad toll in countries that have spent vast sums to attract tourists and investors.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Pilgrims in Mecca carried umbrellas to protect themselves from the intense heat during the hajj this month.

item.title: Israel Orders More Evacuations in Gaza as Military Fights Hamas in Shajaiye
item.description: Palestinian officials and residents described strikes and blasts as Israel’s public broadcaster reported that the Israeli military had returned to fight Hamas in Gaza City’s east.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek, Ephrat Livni, Ameera Harouda and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: Palestinians travel in a donkey-drawn cart as they flee their homes following an Israeli military operation in Shejaiya

item.title: Israeli Soldier Is Killed During Raid in West Bank, IDF Says
item.description: As well as the officer who died, another was severely wounded during the operation in Jenin, a bastion of armed resistance to Israel’s occupation. One Palestinian was also reported wounded.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A crater left by a roadside bomb that targeted an Israeli military jeep in the city of Jenin in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Thursday.

item.title: How a Tiny Circle of Advisers Helped Prod Macron to Call France’s Snap Election
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s governing style has always been intensely top-down. But with far-right nationalists in France closing in on power, some believe he may have gone too far this time.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron has defended his decision to call a snap election as an effort to attain political “clarification” for France.

item.title: Amsterdam Museum to Return a Matisse Work Sold Under Duress in World War II
item.description: The painting, “Odalisque,” was sold to the Stedelijk Museum in the early 1940s by a German-Jewish family desperate to escape the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal

item.title: Shahjahan Bhuiya, Executioner Turned TikTok Star, Dies in Bangladesh
item.description: He hanged high-profile inmates in exchange for a reduction in his own robbery and murder sentences, and became a social media sensation after his release.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Shahjahan Bhuiya holding a copy of his book in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in February.

item.title: Iranians Say, ‘We Have Been Going Backward’
item.description: Iranians say they have little faith their votes in Friday’s presidential election will improve their lives, and many are planning to sit it out.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tajrish Square in Tehran on Wednesday, the last day of campaigning for the presidential election to be held Friday.

item.title: Trump Eyes Bigger Trade War in Second Term
item.description: The former president’s past tariffs raised prices for consumers and businesses, economists say. His next plan could tax 10 times as many imports.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump is envisioning an increase of trade tariffs that some economists say could drive up already high prices and plunge the United States into a recession.

item.title: The Etiquette of Remembering Your Friend’s Pet’s Name
item.description: At a barbershop in Colorado, stylists and customers discussed a matter of social protocol.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel and Theo Stroomer
item.media:credit: Theo Stroomer for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Evan Gershkovich’s trial began in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich before his court hearing yesterday.

item.title: North Korea Says It Tested Multiple-Warhead Missile Technology
item.description: The announcement, coming days after Vladimir V. Putin’s visit to Pyongyang, suggests an ambitious attempt to upgrade the North’s nuclear arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via /Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: North Korean state media said this image depicted a “separation and guidance control test of individual mobile warheads” conducted on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Officials Tour Lebanon Border Amid Escalating Tensions With Hezbollah
item.description: Israeli officials toured the northern border as U.S. officials stressed the need for a diplomatic solution to tensions with the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A fire burning after Israeli forces intercepted a target that crossed into northern Israel from Lebanon. Tensions are rising along the two countries’ shared border.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Evan Gershkovich’s Trial
item.description: Also, Kenya’s president shelved the tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich before his court hearing yesterday.

item.title: Bolivian Soldiers Withdraw and General Is Arrested After Apparent Coup Attempt
item.description: The general declared he was leading an effort to “re-establish democracy,” but he and other members of the armed forces later pulled back after trying to storm the presidential palace.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Genevieve Glatsky and María Silvia Trigo
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Brazil’s Supreme Court Decriminalizes Marijuana Possession for Personal Use
item.description: The country’s Supreme Court voted to remove criminal penalties for possession of up to 40 grams of marijuana.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Demonstrators holding a banner that reads in Portuguese, “Legalize now,” during a march this month in São Paulo.

item.title: Gazans Describe Life on the Verge of Famine
item.description: A panel of global hunger experts warned this week that the Gaza Strip could soon face famine, but to many Gazans, it feels as if one has already arrived.
item.dc:creator: Iyad Abuheweila, Ameera Harouda and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Children receiving food on Monday in Jabaliya, in northern Gaza, this month.

item.title: I.C.C. Convicts Senior Jihadist Police Leader of Atrocities in Timbuktu
item.description: The court said his crimes had involved overseeing public floggings, torture and arbitrary arrests during a jihadist takeover in northern Mali in 2012.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons and Elian Peltier
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Piroschka Van De Wouw
item.media:description: Al Hassan Ag Abdoul Aziz at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, in 2022. He was a police leader in Timbuktu, in northern Mali, under the extremist group Ansar Dine.

item.title: What the Court’s Ruling on Drafting the Ultra-Orthodox Means for Israel
item.description: Israel’s insular ultra-Orthodox community has long been exempt from military service. The Supreme Court’s decision to end that exemption could change the country’s social and political dynamics.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: An ultra-Orthodox man, right, at an army recruitment office on Tuesday in Jerusalem. In a ruling on Tuesday, the Israeli Supreme Court ended ultra-Orthodox Jewish men’s exemption from military service.

item.title: Iran’s Presidential Candidates Agree on One Thing: Trump Is Coming
item.description: The former U.S. president’s election is treated as a foregone conclusion, with the six contenders clashing over who is best suited to handling him.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Black-Clad Ultras Are a Fixture at Euro 2024
item.description: Hard-core fan groups, embracing a strong nationalistic streak, have provoked pushback from soccer’s authorities at the European Championship.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Members of the Carpathian Brigade, a Hungarian ultras group, at a match between Hungary and Switzerland during Euro 2024 this month. The group often echoes the rhetoric of their country’s prime minister, Viktor Orban.
